Her deram is to become a professional, to serve her country, and to have stable employement so that she can help her poor family.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a bathroom.

loans.name: Guida

texts.es: Guida es madre soltera, vive junto a sus 3 hijos que están estudiando y la apoyan mucho. Su dedicación a la venta de comida logró que pudiera construir en su propio domicilio su pequeño restaurante, donde por las noches vende salchipollo (salchicha y pedazos de pollo fritos), debido a que sus clientes se lo pedían, por su buena atención y sazón, se ha ganado el cariño y respeto de sus comensales, ete negocio lo tiene desde hace 10 años, le gusta mucho cocinar bien para que sus clientes se sientan satisfechos. Le es rentable, ya que se encuentra ubicada en una buena zona y le va excelente, nos cuenta. Es su primer préstamo con MFP, por lo que se compromete a ser puntual en sus cuotas. Con el dinero que solicita quiere comprar mesas y sillas, para dar una mejor acogida a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Guida is a single mother who lives with her 3 children who are students and support her a lot. Her dedication selling food enable her to be able to build a small restaurant in her own home, where in the evenings she sells “salchipollo” (sausage and pieces of fried chicken), as this is what her customers ask her to prepare, and because of her good attention and seasoning, she has won the love and respect of her companions. She has had this business for 10 years. She very much enjoys cooking well so that her customers will be satisfied. Her business is profitable, as it is located in a good area and it is going well, she tells us. This is her first loan with MFP, and she promises to be punctual with her payments. With the money she wants to buy tables and chairs to provide a more inviting environment for her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy furniture for her restaurant.

loans.name: Temitope

texts.en:
Temitope is 29 years old and she is single. She sells rechargeable phone cards and she also earns money making calls. She has been in this business for the past three years.

Temitope is the lady in the blue jean skirt in the picture.

She needs a loan of N50,000 so she can purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell. She says thank you to all who will make this loan possible

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: Manuel Antonio

texts.es: Don Manuel tiene 33 años de edad, habita en memorial sandino, junto con su esposa que le tiene dos hijos de 5 y 7 años de edad, uno de los niños va a clase a primer grado en el colegio del barrio, su negocio es la venta de leña y presta el servicio de acarreo en un carretón de caballos, que ha sido su subsistencia ya que la gente ocupa muchos de sus servicios por los bajos costos, su esposa tiene una pequeña pulpería que día a día va creciendo y esperan salir cada día en mejores condiciones, el inicio este negocio por que su papa trabajaba ganándose la vida en este trabajo, y aprendió mucho,es un trabajo cansado, y que la mayor parte anda uno sucio pero es rentable y desea superarse para poder ayudar a su familia, con este préstamo que afodenic, le esta brindando es para hacer las paredes de su casa y poder gozar de una vivienda digna, para esto va  comprar materiales de construcción, como piedra, arena, cemento, hierro entre otros. Sus planes es comprar otro caballo para seguir dando mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Manuel is 33 and lives in the Memorial Sandino neighborhood with his wife and two children, 5 and 7, one of whom is in first grade at the local school. Manuel sells firewood and provides transportation services using his horse and wagon. He spends a lot of time serving his clients for a very low cost, so he just gets by. His wife has a small general store that is growing by the day. They hope to make daily improvements to their quality of life. Manuel chose his business because he learned a lot from his father, who earned his living the same way. His work is tiring and fairly dirty, but it is profitable and he wants to better himself so he can help his family. Manuel is seeking a loan from AFODENIC to build walls for his house so he can enjoy a decent home. He'll need to buy construction materials, such as stone, sand, cement, iron, etc. His plans include buying another horse so he can continue providing better service to his clients.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials to build walls for his house

loans.name: Ana Rosa

texts.es: Ana Rosa C. D. V., ResiD. en Zacatecoluca, junto a su hija, la cuál es madre soltera. Ambas deben trabajar arduamente para poder sostener su hogar y brindarle todas las necesidades básicas a su nieto. Ana Rosa posee su propio negocio, el cuál consiste en vender D. manera ambulante ropa en Zacatecoluca y Santiago Nonualco, así también por las tardes venD. en su propia casa, fruta, helados y charamuscas, las cuales son un tipo D. golosina típica D. El Salvador y son elaboran con jugos naturales los cuales se colocan en una pequeña bolsa plástica y se congela, ella logra vender muy bien este tipo D. golosinas, debido a que en los pueblos es costumbre que los niños coman frutas y charamuscas por las tardes. Ana Rosa solícita un préstamo a través del cuál obtenga el capital necesario para poder aumentar la cantidad D. ropa y poder elaborar más golosinas, y D. esta manera obtener mayores ganancias las cuales contribuyen al sostenimiento D. su hogar y así también a mejorar la calidad D. vida D. su pequeño nieto.
texts.en:
Ana Rosa C. D. V. lives with her daughter and her grandson in Zacatecoluca.Ana Rosa's daughter is a sinlge mother, and both women must work hard to support their home and to proviD. for the child. Ana Rosa sells clothing on the streets in Zacatecoluca and Santiago Nualco. In the afternoons, when she is back home, she sells fruit, ice cream and charamuscas (popsicles), which are maD. by freezing fruit juice in small plastic bags. Sales are good because children in the small towns are used to eat fruit and charamuscas in the afternoon. Ana Rosa is requesting a loan to purchase more clothing and more fruit to make charamuscas. With this loan she expects to produce more and obtain higher profits to support her home and to proviD. a better quality of life for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Maria B., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing clothing wholesale

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline M. is currently in the business of selling bags at the market and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Jackline is 40 years old and is married. Her husband is the head teacher. She has four children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Ravshan

texts.ru: Равшан Жалилов 1975 года рождения женат имеет 2 детей. Он закончил школу и сразу пошел работать мастером ремонтных работ. Он помогал дяде ремонтировать квартиры и дома. Но работа оказалась немного тяжелой и он также начал заниматься откормом скота. Он получает кредит для покупки скота. Его жена ухаживает за скотом, полученное молоко продает, от этого и есть маленький доход. Равшан и его жена планируют расширить коровник и  прикупить еще несколько коров . Они откормят и продадут быстрее, если дадут высокую плату.
texts.en:
Ravshan J. was born in 1975, he is married and has two children. He finished school and started working as a repairman. He was helping his uncle to repair apartments and houses. But this job turned out to be a little too hard and he then started a business raising cattle. He takes out a loan to buy cattle. His wife watches after the livestock and sells the milk from which she makes small income. Rashvan and his wife plan to expand the cow house and buy a few more cows. They will feed them and sell faster if the get a higher price.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Adiaratou

texts.fr:
Madame  Adiaratou O. est mariée et mère de 4 enfants (2 garçons et 2 filles). Elle est née le 24 Janvier 1974 à Sikasso, 3eme région administrative de la république du Mali.  Elle vit avec son mari et leurs enfants à Kadiolo  dans le quartier Noumousso.
Elle mène son activité de commerce d’articles divers depuis 6 ans (vente de draps, de wax, d’ encens, de jus et de la glace). Expérimentée en raison des années d’activité, elle le fait avec réussite.
Elle est à sa deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Le prêt précédent a été remboursé sans difficulté. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt un congélateur,  des tissus  et des draps de lit. Elle s’approvisionne au Burkina Faso, à Sikasso ville, à Kadiolo et environnants. Elle vend au comptant et à crédit (en gros et en détail) à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 45.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne car elle ambitionne acheter un terrain à usage d’habitation à Sikasso ville.
texts.en:
Mrs. Adiaratou O. is married and the mother of 4 children (2 sons and 2 daughters). She was born on January 24, 1974 in Sikasso, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. She lives with her husband and children in Kadiolo in the Noumousso district.

She has had her business selling general merchandise (bedsheets, "wax" brand African print cloth, incense, juice and ice) for 6 years. As she had had a lot of experience, she succeeds very well at this business. She is on her second loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. The preceding loan was reimbursed without difficulty.

With this loan she expects to buy a freezer, some fabric, and bedsheets. She buys her merchandise in Burkino Faso, in the town of Sikasso, and in Kadiolo and its surroundings. She sells for cash or credit (wholesale and retail) to a clientele composed of women and men.

She expects to earn a monthly average profit of 45,000 F CFA of which part will be used to help her husband cover household expenses and the rest will be put into savings since her ambition is to be able to buy a plot of land on which to build a house in the town of Sikasso.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Kossi  Agbenyenu

texts.fr: Ce monsieur exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus le commerce de papiers pour emballages et couverture, ses clients emballent chez lui des cadeaux de mariage et d’anniversaire. Son stock actuel de papier d'emballage ne peut lui permettre de satisfaire ses clients, il demande à WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 35 lots de papiers d’emballages et divers. Il est célibataire et travaille dur pour subvenir à ses propres charges.
texts.en:
This gentleman earns an income from commerce in paper products for wrapping and covering. His customers come to him to wrap their marriage gifts and birthday presents. His current stock of wrapping paper prevents him from satisfying his customers. He's asking WAGES for his first loan to buy 25 lots of wrapping paper and various items. He is unmarried and works hard to support himself.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy paper for wrapping and covering

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is married and the mother of one child. She lives at Dorma Ahenkro in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana with her family. She is 23 years old. She runs a mini shop and has been selling items like blouses and skirts, women's slippers and dressing bags for the past year. She gets her stock of goods from Kumasi which is the nearest city center but she is unable to bring back more.

Patricia is constrained by lack of funds for the business. She needs this loan to inject more working capital into the business to scale up business progress. She believes the loan will help her to be more resourced to purchase good quality and large quantity to upgrade her inventory. She says she would be grateful for your assistance. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Asomdwe’ which means Peace.

loans.use: To purchase jeans, ladies wear, and slippers

loans.name: Aydalina Del Socorro

texts.es: Doña Aydalina Muños, mujer trabajadora que logro poner su propio negocio una pulpería donde vende productos variados el cual administra desde cuatro años, tiene la edad de 38 años, reside en el barrio Laureles Sur en la capital de Managua,  su esposo es comerciante, le tiene dos hijos uno de 19 y otro de 3 años de edad, el mayor es independiente, su negocio lo inicio con dinero que su esposo dio y prestamos en Afodenic  con esto ha logrado incrementar su inventario. Con este préstamo va a comprar granos básicos, productos lácteos, carnes entre otros, para ofrecer a sus clientes. Sus planes es poder hacer grande su negocio.
texts.en:
Aydalina Muños is a hard-working woman who managed to start her own general store, where she sells a variety of products, four years ago. She is 38 years old, and lives in the Laureles Sur neighborhood in the capital city of Managua. Her husband is a merchant, and they have two children ages 19 and 3. The eldest is now living independently. She started her enterprise with money from her husband, as well as loans from Afodenic that have helped her to increase her inventory. With this loan, she will invest in basic grains, dairy products, meats, and other items, to offer to her customers. Her plan is to grow her store into a large business.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase basic grains and dairy products.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen S. is from the village of Polo Pitogo. She is 34 years old. Helen is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Helen owns & operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Helen has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2001, Helen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. Helen is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 14th loan taken out by Helen from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: La Superacion Group

texts.en:
Guillermina S. is a budding entrepreneur who is currently employed in retail clothing sales. She sells new, fashionable clothes from her home and in the streets. The selling of used clothes in the Dominican is big business, but Guillermina has decided to sell new clothes in an effort to separate herself from the masses who are selling used clothes. Her clothes may be more expensive, but the newness of clothes is an effective selling tool.

Even though Guillermina has been successful selling new clothes, she needs capital to really expand her business. It had been very frustrating for her, because she knows that she could expand her business, but she couldn’t find anyone to lend her money. She was extremely ecstatic to learn about Esperanza, and you could tell by listening and talking to her that she was eager to receive her loan and begin investing and growing her business.

loans.use: To purchase a more clothes to sell in her neighborhood

loans.name: Lalotea

texts.en:
Lalotea S. is a 45-year-old woman living in the town of Mulifanua. She is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Lalotea operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Lalotea has been engaged in this business for over 7 years and earns approximately 650 Samoan tala (about $246 US) a month from these activities.

In 2005, Lalotea joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lalotea has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1250 tala from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase a fishing boat. Lalotea is now requesting a new loan of 1000 tala which will be used to invest in expanding the business. The loan will be her third from SPBD. Lalotea plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About SPBD: SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is from the village of Sta. Catalina of Ilagan, Isabela. She is married to Samuel who helps her in their small charcoal production business. She is glad that they also have a small farm which gives them an additional source of income. The couple have three children, all of whom are currently studying. Jane hopes that they will be able to finish their studies so that they can have a better standard of living when they have families of their own.

Jane collects wood to make charcoal and sometimes also buys it for this purpose. To help her business grow, she is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP from Kiva lenders. The income from her business is essential to her family because it is used to provide their basic daily needs.

loans.use: As additional capital

loans.name: Esperanza 2&3 Group

texts.en:
Antoinet is the group coordinator of the group Esperanza (Hope), which is based in the rural area surrounding Santiago, a city in the mid-west region of the country where electricity and running water (not suitable for drinking) is unreliable at best. Here she makes her home with her husband and three primary-school-aged children in a simple rented house of cement blocks and a tin roof. Access to medical supplies and nutrition are also limited – it has been over two years since she was last able to see a doctor and her family typically consumes only two meals per day for lack of regular income.

Despite these obstacles, Antoinet remains confident that her future will be better, and she has come to Esperanza to request her first loan. With this loan she plans to purchase yuca, potatoes, beef, chicken, salami and other cooking items to open a comedor (cafeteria). She hopes that this business will provide a regular income for her family. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase yuca, potatoes, meat, chicken and salami

loans.name: Myra

texts.en:
Myra B. is from the village of Danao. She is 30 years old. Myra is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Myra owns & operates a business making & selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Myra is just starting this business.

In 2008, Myra joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myra has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Myra is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & as working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Myra from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina F. is from the village of Dimalco Bonifacio in Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old. Gina is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Gina owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products and dry goods in the local community. Gina has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Gina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. Gina is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Gina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and to save for future needs.

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Aura Estela

texts.es:
La señora Aura Estela R. posee su propio negocio de pulpería el cuál es atendido por ella misma en su establecimiento ubicado en el mercado El bisne del departamento de Chinandega donde atiende a diario ofreciendo los productos varios como jabones, ase, gaseosas, huevos y otros comestibles ofreciéndolos a todos sus clientes que le visitan.

Actualmente, ella ha acudido a Ceprodel para solicitar el crédito para la compra de los productos para la pulpería y así continuar en su actividad para lograr la satisfacción de sus clientes que a diario le visitan para comprar los productos ofrecidos en la pulpería.
texts.en:
Señora Aura Estela R. owns her own convenience store which is attended by herself in her establishment located in the El bisne market of the department of Chinandega. There she attends daily offering various products such as soaps, cleaning products, carbonated waters, eggs and other foods, offering them to all the clients that visit her. At present, she has responded to Ceprodel to request a loan for the purchase of the products for the store and thus to continue in her business to achieve the satisfaction of her clients that daily visit her to buy the products offered in the store.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products for her convenience store

loans.name: Mary Lucila

texts.es:
La señora Mary es socia del Banco Comunal “San Pedro” ubicado en  la comunidad D. Ancara, del distrito D. Ilave, Provincia D. El Collao, Departamento D. Puno; tiene 45 años D. edad, D. estado civil casada, tiene 06 hijos, vive en la comunidad D. Ancara , ella no tuvo la ocasión D. estudiar.

La señora viene trabajando con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desD. hace 3 años y su préstamo inicial fue D. S/. 300.00 Nuevos Soles, el cual le permitió incrementar su capital para su negocio D. compra venta D. ganado ovino.

En la actualidad requiere D. un nuevo préstamo D. S/. 2000.00 Nuevos soles, el cual le permitirá comprar ganado ovino y también algunos balones D. gas para venderlo en las ferias D. la zona.  Paralelamente se dedica a las labores propias del campo.

Su mayor deseo es continuar trabajando y generar sus propios ingresos.

A ella le  gustan  los ahorros.
texts.en:
Mary is a member of the San Pedro Communal Bank located in the Ancara community in the Ilave district, El Collao province, Puno department. She is 45, married, and has six children. She lives in the Ancara community. She did not have the opportunity to go to school. She has been working with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for three years. Her first loan for 300 PEN allowed her to increase the capital in her business of buying and selling sheep. She currently needs a loan for 2,000 PEN, which will allow her to buy sheep. She will also buy tanks of gas to sell at the regional fairs. She does her own field work at the same time. Her biggest desire is to keep working to generate her own income. She likes the savings.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sheep and tanks of gas

loans.name: Chinbat

texts.en:
D. is 39 years old and lives with his wife and seven-year-old daughter in the Uvurkhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, and his daughter attends a local secondary school. With the help of his wife, D. operates a wooden product business in his town. He began his business in 2000 after borrowing his friend’s woodworking tools. In 2005, he received a loan from XacBank, one of the largest banks in Mongolia, in order to purchase his own woodworking tools. Because he has been in business for almost a decade, D. has increased his business experience and his customer base. He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan in order to purchase wood and other necessary materials for his woodworking business.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

loans.use: To purchase wood and other necessary materials for his woodworking business

loans.name: Tungalag

texts.en:
H. Tungalag is 40 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in Bayanhongor province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a "ger". Her oldest son, Altangerel, is in college, and her youngest, Nemehbayar, attends a local secondary school. Her husband is a driver and manages a transportation service. Tungalag operates a clothing trading business in her town. She sells a variety of clothing items, most of which she imports from China to her many customers. Tungalag started her business in 2001 with capital of 400,000 tugrugs (~280 USD). After years of successful operations she has managed to increase her working capital to a level exceeding 1,500,000 tugrugs (~1,050 USD) today. Her earnings have enabled her to by a car for her husband to use as a taxi. Tungalag is always looking toward the future and hopes her continued success will allow her to provide for her family. She says, “I want my children to become educated people.” She is requesting a 1,200,000 tugrug (~840 USD) loan to purchase clothes from China to sell in her business.

About XacBank:

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All&sectors[]=All&regions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell.

loans.name: Dellilah

texts.en:
Dellilah M. is 56 and widowed with 3 children.  She owns a business venture, selling fried foods in the local community.  Dellilah has 3 years of experience in this business.  Dellilah needs a loan of WST $2000 to buy BBQ meat, ketchup, plastic plates & utensils, and coal.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 550 talas or US $229 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Dellilah joined SPBD.  This is her 2nd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Dellilah's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Dellilah M. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.4 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.8 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2.3 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to buy BBQ meat, ketchup, plastic plates & utensils, and coal

loans.name: Marusya

texts.en:
T. Marusya is a 50-year-old single mother of one teenage son. She lives in the Arkhangai province of central Mongolia. Her son is a student at a university, and Marusya operates a dairy retail business in her local market. 

She began her business in 1999 with a working capital of 100,000 MNT and in the eleven years of being in business, she has managed to increase her working capital to 3,100,000 MNT. She plans to continue to grow her business so that she can help her son in the future as he gets married and eventually starts his own family. 

Marusya is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a large variety of wholesale dairy products which she can sell from her stand for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy cosmetics for resale

loans.name: Puth

texts.en: Puth S., age 63, is married and resides with his wife and child in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. He is a doctor, earning approximately an income of US$ 10 per day. By doing so, he is able to cover family expenses. He has been in this business since 1969. His wife is a tailor, earning an income of US$ 5 per day. The standard of living of this family improved since they have been in these businesses, so they want to have a loan to expand their businesses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to buy more materials to aid his wife's business of tailoring. This is his first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: buy more materials to expand his wife's tailoring business

loans.name: Ambignakola Group

texts.fr:
Les   femmes du groupe  Ambignakola ont en moyenne  39 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles à Zanfina un des villages  de Fana, préfecture de Dioïla, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et font  l’achat vente, du bois de chauffe, de condiments alimentaires et de céréales.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 4 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Ambignakola sont à leur cinquième  prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 2 tonnes de céréales et des colis de plusieurs variétés de condiments alimentaires.
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes et effectuent leurs ventes d’une façon ambulante et au marché de Fana, généralement au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15.000FCFA qui servira à essentiellement étoffer leur fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the group Ambignakola are, on average, 39 years old, with 4 children each and they all live in traditional families in Zafina, one of the towns of Fana, which is a county of Dioïla, the second administrative region of the republic of Mali. These women know one another through neighborhood connections. They sell firewood, food condiments and cereals/ grains. Having fully repaid 4 previous loans, the women of the group Ambignakola are requesting their fifth group loan, which they will use to purchase 2 tons of cereals/ grains and packages of several varieties of condiments. They supply themselves mostly locally from farmers and wholesalers. They do their sales as they walk around town and also in the market of Fana, usually for cash, to a clientele composed of women and men. They envision each earning an average monthly income of 15,000FCFA, which they will use to reinforce their business' funds.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: Glory

texts.en: Glory sells clothes and bags of garri (cassava flakes) at retail prices to make a living in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. Garri is made from cassava and it is a staple food in Nigeria. She is 30 years old and married with a child. Her husband also works to support their home. She is a friendly and happy woman. She says her only challenge is lack of funds and she hopes to overcome this challenge. She needs a loan amount NGN 150,000 to purchase more clothes and bags of garri (cassava flakes) to sell. She hopes to grow her business. She loves her business and family dearly and she hopes to excel in life. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and bags of garri to sell.

loans.name: Sokheng

texts.en: Mrs. Sokheng K. is 46 years old. She is a villager in Daeum Pring village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Phally Meach, are vegetable sellers who earn a small income to support their family. They own two motorcycles and a Khmer trailer to support their business. Since their business is going well, they want to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Sokheng K. decided to ask for a loan to purchase more vegetables. The rest of the loan she will use to buy fish to sell. Mrs. Sokheng K. is a mother of four children. One of the children is a seamstress in a garment factory, two stay at home and support their parent's business, and the youngest is 10 years old. Her husband is on the left in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth A. is single. She has received senior high education.  Elizabeth prepares palm oil for sale at Abura. To prepare her locally made palm oil, she gets her palm nuts from the farmers at their farms.

She washes them then boils them for a while until they become tender. She scoops the cooked fruit into a big mortar and pounds gently with a pestle so as not to damage the nut. She then adds water to the pounded fruit. The pounded fruit is squeezed and filtered to get the juice out and remove the chaff. (The chaff can be used to light charcoal fires).The juice boils again and the fresh oil floats to the surface of the pot. It is scooped into yet another pot to cool. Fresh oil is eaten with roasted yams or plantains.

Elizabeth uses her income to pay utility bills and accommodation.  Elizabeth will use the loan to purchase more palm fruit to process palm oil for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Elizabeth plans to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: Elizabeth will use the loan to purchase more palm fruit to process palm oil for sale.

loans.name: Mrs. Kimly San Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank is comprised of seventeen people, living in Krang Ta Mung village in Takeo province. Mrs. Kimly S. is a village bank president, selected by all the members. Each member will use their portion of the loan for different purposes in order improve the living conditions their families. Her problem is that it is time to farm their rice field. So, to improve production rice, Mrs. Kimly S. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, to hire farming laborers to plow the rice field, and rest of the loan she wants to start a new business breeding piglets. Her husband, Mr. Kork Horn, is a construction worker. They have three children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is helping to do farming, and the other is studying in the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, to hire farming laborers to plow rice field.

loans.name: Neang

texts.en:
Neang N., 38, lives in Battambang Province and earns a low income. She is a good and determined mother who tries to feed her four children, all of whom attend school. Her husband is a bicycle repairman.
Neang N. sells fresh fish in the market to earn a living. Every day in the late morning, she goes to a place that is full of fisherman to buy fish in bulk. Then she hurries to the market, where she sells the fish retail. Neang N. is requesting a loan to purchase an old vehicle to transport the fish. With any remaining cash from the loan, she will build a small pigpen where she plans to raise a few pigs for extra revenue.

loans.use: To purchase an old vehicle for transportation

loans.name: An

texts.en:
Mrs. An L., 37 years old, lives in the province of Siem Reap, Cambodia, where she owns and farms a plot of land next to her house, growing mushrooms to sell when they come to maturity. She plants her crops twice a year, and she was taught how to grow mushrooms by her grandparents. She has been married for many years to her husband, but this couple has no children yet. Her husband assists with her in planting mushrooms. In addition, he also teaches his nearby villagers how to plant mushrooms well for a fee. 

Mrs. An L. has requested a loan to purchase essential equipment that she uses to establish more locations for growing mushrooms.

loans.use: To establish more locations for growing mushrooms

loans.name: Gladys

texts.es: Gladys tiene 47 años, comparte su vida con su pareja y sus dos hijos, Joel de 17 años y Jaquelin  de 14 años. Juntos viven en su casa propia. Hace mas de 1 año se dedica en la venta de productos de belleza, negocio al cual incursionó gracias al consejo de sus amigas, quienes frecuentemente le comentaban las buenas ganancias que obtenían con esta labor. Es así que Gladys decidió trabajar en este rubro, logrando obtener experiencia, además sus amigas y vecinas continuamente le hacen variados pedidos de sus productos, por lo que espera tener muchas ganancias. Por otra parte, también se dedica al tejido a mano de prendas de vestir como: ropa de bebe, chalinas guantes, entre otros, generándole un ingreso extra a su economía. En un futuro desea instalar otro negocio, como una librería y bazar a la vez, pero dentro de su propia casa, pues cree que es un negocio fijo y mucho más rentable y seguro. Este es su primer crédito con MFP y siempre se caracterizo por ser muy responsable con sus pagos. Con el crédito que solicita, desea comprar variados productos de belleza, para que pueda tener en stock.
texts.en:
Gladys is 47 years old. She shares her life with her husband and two children, Joel 17 years old and Jaquelin 14 years old. They live together in their own house. She has been selling beauty products for more than 1 year, a business she got into thanks to the advice of her friends. They often mentioned the good earnings they got from this job. That is how Gladys decided to work at this trade and got experience. Her friends and neighbors continually give her orders for her products that she hopes to earn a lot from. On the other hand, she also works hand knitting clothing, baby clothes and gloves among other things, to generate additional earnings. She would like to start another business in the future, like a bookstore and shop together but inside her own house. She thinks it is a more stable business and more profitable and safer. This is her first loan with MFP. She has always been known to be responsible with her payments. She would like to buy varied beauty products to have in stock with the loan she is applying for.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase varied beauty products.

loans.name: Herlinda

texts.es: Herlinda, de 37 años, es una mujer alegre y emprendedora que vive con su pareja Walter de 38 años, con quien tiene 2 hermosos hijos. Está familia vive juntos en su casa propia. Sus dos hijos son su motivación para esmerarse en el trabajo cada día, por eso desde hace 5 años, se dedica a cultivar café y plátano, además es negociante de frutas oriundas de la selva peruana, siendo éstas adquiridas de sus vecinos que producen dichas frutas, de las cuales compra, los encajona y los traslada hacia los mercados de “Huancayo” y “Lima” para su comercialización. Por otro lado su cónyuge brinda el servicio de transporte público, y durante los días que descansa, ayuda a Herlinda en la agricultura y en el negocio. Ella disfruta de la tranquilidad del campo, sin embargo le parece difícil tener que trasladar sus productos hasta los mercados, por eso los acopia lo cosechado en su tienda. Aunque este oficio, no la desalienta le parece sacrificado pero a la vez rentable, porque gracias a las utilidades, puede brindarle una adecuada calidad de vida a su familia, por tal motivo piensa continuar plantando café pero sobre todo incrementar y surtir de productos en su establecimiento. Esta es la segunda  vez que tiene un crédito con MFP y asegura que continuará laborando de manera activa en su grupo comunal. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará más frutas para continuar con la comercialización al por mayor y además comprar llantas para el carro de su esposo.
texts.en:
Herlinda, age 37, is a happy and enterprising woman. She lives with her life partner, 38 year old Walter, and their two beautiful children. This family lives together in their own house. Her two children are the motivation for her to do her best at work everyday. She has been growing coffee and bananas for five years. Also, she is a businesswoman selling fruit from the Peruvian jungle. She gets them from her neighbors who produce these fruits. She buys them, boxes them, and takes them to the Huancayo and Lima markets to sell. Her life partner offers public transportation services. On his days off he helps Herlinda with the farming and in the business. She enjoys the tranquility of the fields. Nevertheless, it is difficult for her to take her products to the markets. That is why she stocks her store with the harvest. Even though this job does not discourage her, it is seemingly self-sacrificing. At the same time it is profitable. Thanks to the profits she is able to give an adequate quality of life to her family. That is why she plans to continue planting coffee, and most of all, she will increase her products and stock her establishment with them. This is her second loan with MFP. She pledges to continue working in an active manner in her communal bank. She will use the requested loan to buy more fruit in order to continue selling it wholesale. She will also buy tires for her husband’s car.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more fruit and sell it wholesale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more timber to fix beds, chairs and other funiture

loans.name: Rispha

texts.en:
Rispha J. is a woman of 33 yearsof age, married to Stephen Maiyo and together they have four children. They live in Strawberg in the outskirts of Eldoret town. She has a cafe in the same area where she sells cooked food.  She has been in business for five years and earns a monthly income of six thousand shillings.

This will be Rispha's sixth loan with Kiva partner KADET. She plans to buy cooking fat for 6500 shillings, five trays of eggs, six bundles of baking flour, etc.  She plans to support her children by paying their school fees and buying them food with the additional income she will earn.

In the future she hopes to educate her children to the highest level and also to provide for their basic needs such as food, clothes and shelter.

loans.use: To buy baking flour, eggs, cooking oil etc.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en: Edith K. lives in the Ntinda Kulambiro neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of her mother. Edith has a business sewing sweaters. She has been in this business for 2 years and she works 6 days out of every week. Edith sells her products at nearby schools by means of wholesale/retail.  Edith has requested for a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more thread and needles for making sweaters.  The main business challenges for Edith are transportation and seasonality. She also generates additional income through rental rooms and rearing chickens. Edith lives in a home that she owns and has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include paying utility bills, food and school fees. Edith's goal for her business is to one day own a sweater factory.

loans.use: To buy more thread and needles for making sweaters

loans.name: Ngalla

texts.en:
Ngalla M. B. is a married man with four children between nine years and one year old. His business is located at Shibu Tumaini in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attraction sites--not forgetting the Indian Ocean's white beaches. 

He has been selling shoes to the local people for the last four years. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is insufficient funds. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy more shoes to expand his business and sell at wholesale to other retailers. 

He also hopes to diversify his business so that when shoes sales are low, he still can continue with his business profitably. He describes himself as patient, determined and open minded.

loans.use: expanding store inventory

loans.name: Kodzo

texts.fr: kodzo est un homme de 36 ans, il est un enseignant de profession. pour accroître ses revenu il s'est lancé dans le commerce de détail de cartes de recharges téléphoniques. il  a une ancienneté de 3 ans dans ce commerce et s'approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé. Sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. la demande actuelle de sa clientèle est élevée. Il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de 2 cartons de cartes de recharges ILLICO, 5 cartons de cartes de recharge TOGOCELL et 5 cartons de recharges MOOV. Avec ce stock il compte satisfaire toutes sa clientèle. il est marié et père d'un enfant.
texts.en: Kodzo, 36, is a teacher. To increase his income, he  also sells rechargeable telephone cards. He has been doing this for three years and buys his stock at the big market in Lomé. His clientele is made up of all sorts of people. The demand from his clientele is presently higher so he is asking WAGES for a loan to buy two boxes of ILLICO brand rechargeable phone cards, five boxes of TOGOCELL, and five boxes of MOOV. With this amount  of inventory, he believes he can satisfy the needs of all his customers. He is married and the father of one child.

loans.use: purchase of a number of boxes of rechargeable phone cards

loans.name: Beatrice Auma

texts.en:
Beatrice B. is 27 years old and has four children between 3 and 7 years old. She is married to Ezekiel B.. 

Beatrice has a hotel (a mini restaurant) that she has been running for the past three years. She is applying for her third loan from KADET LTD and has a good credit history with KADET. Her monthly income comes to 18,000 Kenyan shillings per month. She intends to use the money to buy some utensils and cooking ingredients for her hotel. The profits made will basically be used to pay school fees for her children and to cater for the family needs.

Her hopes and dreams are to see her business grow and to open another hotel in the neighboring town.

loans.use: Buy utensils and cooking ingredients

loans.name: Momo

texts.en:
Momo is a married woman with one boy aged 12 who is attending school. She rents a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is clothing.

She operates a restaurant from home, and neighbours and passers by are her major customers. Momo faces competition from nearby restaurant operators. She hopes to build her own home in the future. 

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings she wants to purchase packets of washing soap, cooking oil, rice, maize and beans for her restaurant. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase packets of washing soap, cooking oil, rice, maize and beans for her restaurant.

loans.name: Eva Concepcion

texts.es:
la sra. Eva R. se dedica al comercio, cuenta con una pulpería desde hace varios años y vende productos de la canasta básica familiar. su pulperia esta ubicada en la colonia Simón Azcona frente a la Escuela Rafael Pineda Ponce, Eva administra muy bien su negocio ya que lo atiende personalmente,  de este negocio le ha dado la crianza a sus hijos ya que enviudo desde hace mas de 10 años y una vez faltándole su esposo lucho y siguió adelante con el fin de sacar adelante a sus hijos, su negocio es bien visitado por sus clientes.
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de mercadería para tener mas surtido su negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Eva R. has had a general store for several years and sells staple goods. Her store is in the community Simon Azcona, in front of the school Rafael Pineda Ponce.
 
She manages her business very well because she does it personally and her costumers visit it regularly. It has been her household only source of income since she has been a widow for over 10 years. After her husband passed away, she continued to work hard to make sure her children are well provided for.  

The loan will be used to buy goods to stock up her store.

loans.use: To buy staple goods for her store,

loans.name: Wilfred Kimutai

texts.en:
Wilfred Kimutai K. has been selling new clothes in Eldoret for the past nine years. From this business he is able to earn a profit of Kshs 15,500 per month. Wilfred is 31 years old, married to Hellen Cheplagat Mutai and they have one child who is 4 years old. 

He is applying for his seventh loan from KADET LTD of KES 50,000 after successfully paying back his other loans. He plans to use the funds to buy supplies of various kinds of new clothes to sell, especially during this festive season. With the anticipated profits from the expanded business, he plans to open a business for the wife in Iten town. 

In the future Wilfred wishes to operate a large boutique and create job opportunities for other people.  His deeper desire is to live a good and blessed life.

loans.use: To buy various kinds of  new clothes

loans.name: Raquel

texts.en:
Raquel G. is a 53-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store business.  She lives in Prk. Yanog, Brgy. Tampalon, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2009 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP10,000. 

Raquel is borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her fourth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP8,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Raquel aspires to improve her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.  

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon -- a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Dionicia

texts.es: La señora Dionicia nacida el 24 de marzo en Chuquisaca,  hace 25 años logra comprarse una parcela en el Porvenir 85,  distante a 32 km de El Torno,  pertenece a la provincia de Cordillera. La señora se dedica a la agricultura siembra maíz sorgo y sésamo, el  dinero del crédito lo utilizara en la compra de semillas y lo que ocasiona los gastos del preparado de la tierra para la siembra por eso la señora trabaja con Emprender hace 4 años por la facilidad de pago que se le da a ella y es una buena cliente, esta agradecido con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en: Dionicia was born on March 24th in Chuquisaca.  25 years ago she managed to buy a plot of land in Porvenir 85, 32km from El Torno, in Cordillera province.  Dionicia is a farmer.  She grows corn, sorghum and sesame.  She will use her loan money to buy seeds and to cover the costs of getting her land ready for sowing.  Dionicia has been working with Emprender for 4 years because of the loan facilities that they provide her with.  She is a good client and is grateful to the institution for the support that she receives.

loans.use: To buy seeds

loans.name: Ihab

texts.en:
Ihab J. is a young man from Tulkarem, a warm city famous for its citrus fruits. Ihab is a single young man living with his parents, sisters and brothers. He helps his family with the income he makes working in an auto repair workshop.

As Ihab wants to increase his income, he has come to FATEN to request a loan to start a small vegetable and fruit stall. Ihab is a respected young man known in the city for his good reputation, which he thinks will help him attract a good number of customers and so increase his family's income.

loans.use: To start a fruit and vegetable stall

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
Mrs. Perla E. is 57 years old, married to a fisherman and has three adult-aged children. She lives in Lobogon barangay within the municipality of Aloran, Misamis Occidental province of the Mindanao islands. Perla sells a variety of fish to the local community, earning 4000 PHP a month.

Perla is glad that she's been a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative since 2007. She was able to get financial assistance from PMPC as well as other benefits available to members. Perla needs additional working capital for her fish sales business and is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan.

In the future Perla wants to own a stall in the public market where it would be easier to sell her fish. She would be happy if all her children could be stable and happy in their own families.

loans.use: As working capital for her fish sales business

loans.name: Claverina

texts.en:
Claverina S. is from the village of Sta Lucia, Quirino, Isabela. She is 60 years old, married and has 3 adult-aged children. Claverina owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Claverina has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2008, Claverina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Claverina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase breeding livestock. Claverina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase breeding livestock. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Claverina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Angela Yolanda

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal La Inmaculada, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, por ser una zona con gran vegetación.

La señora Angela es socia fundadora del Banco comunal y le gusta porque los intereses son más bajos que en otras instituciones de crédito. Tiene 43 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene dos hijos los cuales ya son mayores de edad, la menor aun viven con ella y estudia en  la  Universidad. Su esposo es mecánico automotriz.

Ella realiza los créditos para ayudar a su esposo que tiene un taller de mecánica automotriz, para que el pueda comprar ciertas herramientas que aún le faltan para brindar un mejor servicio, él esposo  trabaja en su taller todos los días desde las 8h00 hasta las 18h00 y a veces hasta más tarde cuando tiene mucho trabajo. Su especialidad son los remaches, nos cuenta que el  lleva con su taller ya por 16 años y que gracias a Dios le ha ido muy bien ya que no le falta el trabajo.

Este crédito es para comprar ciertas herramientas y materia prima para los remaches. Sus sueños son tener un carro en el futuro.
texts.en:
Every two weeks, the 'La Inmaculada' community bank meets in the city of Tosagua.  This area is known for being very dynamic.  Most of its inhabitants work in crop farming and livestock raising.  It is an area with a lot of vegetation.

Angela is a founding member of her community bank and she likes it because the interest rates are lower than those of other institutions.  Angela is 43 years old, married, and has two grown-up children.  The youngest still lives with her and is studying at university.  Her husband is a mechanic.

Angela is taking a loan to help her husband, who has a garage, so that he can buy certain tools that he still needs in order to provide his customers with a better service.  Her husband works in his garage every day from 8.00am to 6.00pm and sometimes until later when there is a lot of work.  His speciality is doing bodywork.  She tells us that he has owned his garage for 16 years and, thanks to God, it has done very well since he is never short of work.

This loan will be used to buy certain tools and materials for her husband so that he can do his bodywork.  Angela's dream is to own a car in the future.

loans.use: To buy tools and rivets

loans.name: Mrs. Sam Art Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam Art, who was born in 1977, is a village bank president who has been selected by 17 people who make up a village bank loan. The members will use their portions of the loan in different ways to improve their families' standard of living. 

Mrs. Sam Art is a sausage seller in the local market where she can earn some profit to support her family. She is the mother of five children, two of whom are construction workers, and the others are enrolled in local public school. 

Her husband, Mr. Vuthy, is a construction worker. 

In the present, her house is not comfortable to live in because it does not have a lavatory. S. to improve this condition, Mrs. Sam Art is applying for a loan to build a lavatory.

loans.use: to build a lavatory

loans.name: Dulcesima

texts.en:
Dulcesima F. is from the village of Rang-ay, Dagatkidavao, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 42 years old. Dulcesima is married and has 9 school-aged children. To make a living, Dulcesima owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and raising pigs for sale. Dulcesima has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Dulcesima joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dulcesima is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Dulcesima from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Jossie

texts.en:
Jossie P. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 44 years old. Jossie is married and has four adult children. Jossie makes and sells snacks & other delicacies like rice & cheese cakes in the local community. Jossie has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2008, Jossie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 17,000 PHP and was used to purchase additional ingredients & working capital.

This loan will be her sixth from HSPFI. Jossie is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to to purchase raw ingredients needed like flour, eggs & sugar. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients like flour, eggs, & sugar

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Jean Paul

texts.en: Jean Paul is 40 years old and is not married. He sells food items, such as sorghum and beans. He has done this business for 5 years. This business has enabled him to support his mother, with whom he lives.  It has helped him meet their needs and increase his capital.  Jean Paul is requesting a loan to buy more food items and hence to make more profits.  In the photo are several sacks with different food items.

loans.use: to buy food items for sale.

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es:
El señor Francisco tiene ya más de seis años dedicándose a la elaboración y venta de comida preparada. 
Al negocio le esta haciendo falta equipo de inmobiliario nuevo y hacerle algunas reparaciones al local. 
Esta solicitando un préstamo para poder comprar el equipo y pagarle a la persona que se encargara de realizar la mejorar al negocio.
Planea pagar el crédito con algunas partes de las ganancias que obtiene del negocio ya que es la fuente de ingreso que tiene para darles lo mejor a su familia.
texts.en: Francisco has had a business making and selling prepared food items for more than 6 years.  He needs some new equipment for his business and also needs to make some repairs to the premises.  He is requesting a loan so that he can buy the equipment and pay a person to make the repairs.  He plans to pay back this loan with part of the earnings he gets from his business, as this business is the source of income that he uses to provide for his family.

loans.use: to buy equipment and make repairs to his business premises

loans.name: Mayllory

texts.es:
La Sra. Mayllory pertenece al Banco Comunal “El Abiseo”, Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia de  Mariscal, Departamento de San Martín. Es casada, tiene 49  años  tiene tres  hijos dos de ellos ya cuentan con familia propia, el menor de 10 años cursa estudios primarios. 

Por iniciativa propia se inició con un capital de S/ 300.00 nuevos, ella se dedica a la venta de ropa para damas caballeros y niños, negocio que le da muy buenas ganancias y le brinda muchas satisfacciones.

Con este préstamo de S/ 3000.00, comprará vestidos, blusas, pantalones, polos, faldas, adicional a esto invertirá en la compra de espejos pequeños, aceitillos, ganchos, carmines y otros productos  para brindar una  buena atención a sus clientes. 

La Sra. Mayllory   es una mujer trabajadora y entusiasta,  su sueño es tener una boutique.  Está muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a salir adelante.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mayllory belongs to the “El Abiseo” Communal Bank, located in the district of Juanjui, province of Mariscal, department of San Martín. She is married, 49 years old and has three children two of which have their own families, the youngest is 10 years old and is in primary school.

Through her own initiative, Mayllory began working with a capital of S/ 300.00 nuevos soles, she sells clothes for women, men and children. The business gives her good profits and a lot of satisfaction.

With a loan of S/ 300.00 nuevos she will buy dresses, blouses, pants, polo shirts, and skirts, as well as small mirrors, oils, hangers, lipstick and other products to give good service to her customers.

Mrs. Mayllory is a hardworking and enthusiastic woman; her dream is to have a boutique. She is very grateful to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for helping women like her get ahead in life.

loans.use: buy dresses, blouses, pants, polo shirts, and skirts.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita works hard to support her family. She is married and has a school supplies and medicines sales business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for eighteen years.

Carmelita requested a 20,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy more school supplies and medicines to sell. In the future, she would like to save money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase school supplies and medicines to sell.

loans.name: Dyanamique Group

texts.fr: La cliente Chibonga, représente du groupe d’affaire « Dynamique » est entrepreneur, âgée de 39 ans, femme vivant seule, mère de 2 enfants qui  étudient tous.  Elle est vendeuse de souliers usés au long de la rue ambiante de Katoyi-Quartier Mabanga. Depuis  2007, elle exerce cette activité. Cependant, elle vient de réaliser  6 cycles avec le crédit de Hekima dans la banque communautaire. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir  de s’approvisionner  avec  20 paires de souliers usés et le reste d’argent  sera affecté dans les petits projets de la famille.  En plus, elle ambitionne scolariser ses enfants et acheter une parcelle pour y construire sa maison.  La cliente remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Le groupe « Dynamique » reste caractériser par le travail et le succès dans les affaires.
texts.en: The customer, Chibonga, who represents the "Dynamique" business group, is a 39 year old female entrepreneur, who lives by herself and has two children who are both studying. She sells used shoes along the busy Katoyi district road in Mabanga. She has been carrying out this business since 2007 and during this time has had six community banking loans from Hekima. This new loan will allow her to get 20 pairs of used shoes, and the rest of the money will be used for small family projects. Furthermore, her ambition is to be able to educate her children and to buy a piece of land on which to build a house. The customer is grateful to Hekima for its actions in favor of poor women who cannot access classic banks. The "Dynamique" group is characterised by work and success in business.

loans.use: to pay for 20 pairs of used shoes

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.en:
Alejandra is 54 years old and married with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell.

Alejandra has borrowed and repaid five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 11 years and also earns an income from buying and selling recycled materials.

Alejandra aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Conrada

texts.en:
Conrada is 54 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. 

Conrada has a retail shop that sells beverages, canned goods & snacks. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Conrada is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Conrada hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Thioro

texts.fr: Madame Thioro est âgée de 44 ans et est mère de 4 enfants. Elle vend au marché central de la ville diverses marchandises. Elle s'approvisionne un peu partout dans le pays. Avec ce prêt qu'elle sollicite, elle comptait s'approvisionner en produits de mer ( poissons séchés, poissons fumés....) et d'autres produits qu'elle va acheter au sud du pays .
texts.en: Madame Thioro is 44 and the mother of four children. She sells various goods in the central market of the town. She buys her merchandise here and there in the country. With the loan she is requesting, she intends to stock up on seafood (dried fish, smoked fish, etc.) and other products that she will buy in the south of the country.

loans.use: to stock up on merchandise.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Mrs. Sok has spent her life cultivating crops. This is a skill she learned from her grandparents when she was young. She is now married and has four children, all of them school-ag and unemployed. Her husband works in the farm fields frequently alongside her. Growing crops is an annual activity in which she has had great success. She is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. The coming rainfall is good for her crop but she doesn’t have enough equity yet to use on her farm. So, Sok is looking for a loan to purchase fertilizers, insecticides, a pump machine, and seeds for planting. Mrs. Sok is very grateful to all lenders that support her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, insecticides, a pump machine, and seeds for planting.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly is 54 years old and married with two children. She has been running a general store in the Philippines for ten years and also earns an income from farming sugarcane.

Nelly works hard to provide for her family. She has borrowed and paid off seventeen loans from NWTF. She is now requesting a 15,000 PHP loan to buy more stock to sell in her general store.

Nelly aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en:
Geoffrey is 41 years old and married. Geoffrey sells fruits and vegetables in Majaoni, Mombasa. His business has been in operation for the last four years and it has been a success. 

This marks his first borrowing from KADET LTD to finance his business. He plans to expand his business by purchasing more coconuts, potatoes, cabbage, spinach, onions and a variety of fruits.  

The anticipated profits will be used to repay the loan and to gradually expand his business. His dream is to become a successful businessman.

loans.use: to purchase more coconuts, potatoes, cabbage, spinach, onions and a variety of fruits

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en:
Florentina is proud to share that through the income she earns from the direct selling of cosmetics she can provide the daily allowances for her three children in school. Now, two children have finished their college, hold degrees and are professionals.
 
Florentina is 53 years of age and happy to say that she is married to a farmer. She dreams of finishing her youngest child to her college level of education, and that's why she is keeping on selling make up, face powder, lipstick and eyeliner. She learned this type of business through friends and relatives. She is proud that she has been 11 years in this business. 

Florentina is asking for a loan of P12,000 to buy lotion, shampoo, fragrances and eye shadow. She hopes to meet the demands of her customers around their village and earn a higher income.

loans.use: to buy lotion, shampoo, fragrances and eye shadow.

loans.name: Saleh's Group

texts.en:
Saleh is a 45-year-old housewife who performs her household responsibilities at home.  She is very caring and her family is very happy with her nature.  Saleh’s husband is a fruit seller who sells fresh, seasonal fruit to his customers for a good profit.  She is the mother of two daughters who are both very young and have not yet started their education. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband’s business.  He will buy fresh, seasonal fruit in bulk to increase his sales and profit.  Saleh’s husband has been in this business for many years and she is confident that an investment will make his business more profitable. 
Note: “In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Saleh”.

loans.use: to support her husband's business so he can buy fresh,seasonal fruit in bulk to sell.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita is 39 years old and married with two children. She works hard to provide for her family. 

Rosita runs a general store in the Philippines. She has been running it for five years and also earns an income from a carenderia (local eatery). She has requested a PHP 49,500 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell. Rosita has borrowed and repaid six loans from NWTF prior this loan. 

Rosita aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to build a room, to have better living conditions and more comfort.

loans.name: Elvia Argentina

texts.es:
Doña Elvia Argentina, de 65 años de edad, tiene 3 hijos de 23, 32 y 40 años de edad, Dos hijos viven en los Estados Unidos  y uno vive con ella y dos nietas,  de 6 y 10 años de edad, quienes están estudiando en la escuela. Ella es madre soltera, vive en la aldea Terencio Sierra de Tela,  Atlántida. 
Su negocio es la venta de ropa clasificada para damas y niños, zapatos, perfumes, cremas y accesorios para damas. Este negocio lo tiene en su casa, desde hace 5 años. Anteriormente   trabajaba como cocinera en hoteles, restaurante y mercados.  Luego uno de sus hijos comenzó enviándole ropa y zapatos de los EE.UU en pequeñas cantidades y al ver que los vendía fue surtiendo de mas productos, y  ya tiene sus clientes que le hacen encargos. 
Le dedica tiempo completo el viernes y el sábado porque son los días en que sus clientes cuentan con dinero.
Ha solicitado un préstamo a ODEF para comprar ropa nueva y perfumes para tener más surtido el negocio.
Su plan es obtener un local para establecer este negocio con la ayuda de los financiamientos y con las ganancias lograr que sus nietas culminen sus estudios.
texts.en:
Elvia Argentina is 65 years old.  She has three children; ages 23, 32, and 40.  Two of her children live in the United States.
